para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Complete Streets.
para.text: "Complete Streets" means a transportation philosophy that calls for streets to be constructed and operated in a way that considers the needs of all users and enables equitable and safe access.

para.heading: Advisory Committee.
para.text: "Advisory Committee" means the Complete Streets Advisory Committee established by this subtitle.

para.heading: Public transit vehicle.
para.text: "Public transit vehicle" means any vehicle that:
is of a type used primarily for the transportation of the general public; and
has a seating capacity of 10 or more passengers.

para.heading: Street.
para.text: "Street" means any street, boulevard, road, highway, alley, lane, sidewalk, footway, mall, esplanade, or other way or place that is owned by the City or habitually used by the public.

para.heading: Transportation Department; Department.
para.text: "Transportation Department" or "Department" means the Baltimore City Department of Transportation.

para.heading: Transportation Director; Director.
para.text: "Transportation Director" or "Director" means the Director of the Baltimore City Department of Transportation or the Director's designee.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, this subtitle applies to all project phases undertaken by or, under the authority of the Transportation Department for the improvement of any street and public right of way, including planning, programming, design, acquisition of land, construction, construction engineering, reconstruction, rehabilitation, resurfacing, retrofit, and operation.

para.heading: Exceptions – Ordinary maintenance.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to ordinary maintenance, such as mowing, cleaning, sweeping, pothole filling, concrete joint repair, and other regular or seasonal maintenance. Ordinary maintenance includes local road resurfacing on roadway segments, exclusive of intersections, that experience traffic volumes of fewer than 6,000 vehicles per day, based on the latest available or estimated traffic data.

para.heading: Exceptions – Preexisting projects.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to a project at or above 30% design or under construction as of January 3, 2020.

para.heading: Exceptions – Limited-access roads.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to a street where use by both pedestrians and bicyclists is prohibited by law.

section.heading: Department to construct and operate system.
section.text: The Department must construct and operate a comprehensive Complete Streets Transportation System that enables access, mobility, economic development, attractive public spaces, health, and well-being for all people.

section.heading: System to ensure safety, etc., and convenience of all users.
section.text: This Transportation System must be designed and operated in ways that ensure the safety, security, comfort, access, and convenience of all users of the streets, including pedestrians, bicyclists, public transit users, emergency responders, transporters of commercial goods, motor vehicles, and freight providers.

section.heading: System to include connected facilities accommodating all travel modes.
section.text: This Transportation System must include integrated networks of connected facilities accommodating all modes of travel.

section.heading: System to promote walking, biking, and public transit.
section.text: This Transportation System must, to the greatest extent possible, promote walking, biking, and public transit.

section.heading: System to promote economic development.
section.text: This Transportation System must, to the greatest extent possible, promote economic development.

section.heading: System to ensure equity.
section.text: This Transportation System must, to the greatest extent possible, ensure equity by actively pursuing the elimination of health, economic, and access disparities.

section.heading: System may be constructed incrementally.
section.text: This Transportation System may be achieved through projects that fully implement complete streets or projects that incrementally implement complete streets through a series of smaller improvements over time.

section.heading: Committee established.
section.text: There is a Complete Streets Advisory Committee.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Advisory Committee comprises the following officials (or their respective designees):
the Transportation Director;
the Director of the City Department of Planning;
the Director of City Department of Public Works;
The Commissioner of the Department of Housing and Community Development; and
The Chief of the Baltimore City Fire Department.

para.heading: Participation by and collaboration with Maryland Transit Administration.

para.text: The Chair of the Committee must include and extend to the Maryland Transit Administration (MTA) all invitations and opportunities for participation with the Advisory Committee as would be extended to any statutory member, exactly as if MTA were a member of the Committee.
Further, the Chair must, to the greatest extent possible, foster the strongest possible collaboration with MTA to pursue the goals of this subtitle.

para.heading: Chair.
para.text: The Transportation Director is the Chair of the Advisory Committee.

para.heading: Subcommittees.
para.text: Subcommittees may be established.

para.heading: Meetings.
para.text: The Advisory Committee meets on the call of the Chair as frequently as required to perform its duties and at least once per quarter.

para.heading: Quorum.
para.text: A majority of the members constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business.

para.heading: Voting.
para.text: An affirmative vote of at least a majority of a quorum is needed for any official action.

para.heading: Required.
para.text: Minutes must be taken of all meetings of the Advisory Committee.

para.heading: Public availability.
para.text: The minutes of every meeting must be made publically available by posting on the Transportation Department's website within 7 days of the meeting.

section.heading: Staff.
section.text: The Transportation Department must provide staff for the Advisory Committee.

section.heading: Duties.
section.text: In addition to the other duties specified elsewhere in this subtitle, the Advisory Committee is responsible for:

para.text: promoting interagency cooperation in project identification, funding, and planning;
reviewing proposals for projects brought to the Committee by any of its members;
reviewing the status of projects to which this subtitle is applicable;
making recommendations to the Director about prioritization of projects;
reviewing reports on complete streets implementation, compliance, and performance; and
coordinating interagency cooperation in community engagement.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this Part IV, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Transit street.
para.text: "Transit street" means any street on which a public transit vehicle provides fixed-route service.

para.heading: Truck route.
para.text: "Truck route" means any street so designated on the Transportation Department's map of "Official Truck Routes".

para.heading: "Design vehicle" defined.
para.text: In this section, "design vehicle" means a selected vehicle, with specific weight, dimensions, and operating characteristics, used to establish street design controls.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The design vehicle used by the Transportation Department for all streets, except for transit streets and truck routes, must be the design vehicle recommended for neighborhood streets by the most recent edition of the National Association of City Transportation Officials, "Urban Street Design Guide".

para.heading: Transit streets.
para.text: The design vehicle used by the Transportation Department for transit streets must be the design vehicle recommended for designated transit streets by the most recent edition of the National Association of City Transportation Officials, "Transit Street Design Guide".

para.heading: Truck routes.
para.text: The design vehicle used by the Transportation Department for truck routes must be the design vehicle recommended for designated truck routes by the most recent edition of the National Association of City Transportation Officials, "Urban Street Design Guide".

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Design speed.
para.text: "Design speed" means the speed used to determine geometric features of a street during the design phase.

para.heading: Target speed.
para.text: "Target speed" means the desired driver speed recommended by street typology.

para.heading: Standard.
para.text: The design speed must be equal to the target speed and posted speed limit on any local, collector, and non-interstate arterial.

para.heading: "Shared street" defined.
para.text: In this section, "shared street" means a street developed for mixed use by low volumes of slow-moving vehicular traffic mixed with high levels of walking.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in this section or otherwise required by law, the lanes of any street may not be more than 10 feet wide, but 9 feet is the preferred width.

para.heading: Local streets.
para.text: On a street designated on the Baltimore City Roadway Functional Classification Map as "local", lanes may not be more than 9 feet wide.

para.heading: Transit streets and truck routes.
para.text: On a transit street or truck route, 1 lane in each direction may be up to 11 feet wide.

para.heading: Shared streets.
para.text: On a street designated as a "shared street", lane width restrictions do not apply.

section.heading: DoT to use latest and best standards.
section.text: In constructing and operating its Complete Streets Transportation System, the Transportation Department must use the latest and best standards, including:

para.text: National Association of City Transportation Officials:
"Global Street Design Guide".
"Urban Street Design Guide".
"Transit Street Design Guide".
"Urban Bikeway Design Guide".
"Urban Street Stormwater Guide".
American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials:
"Guide for Planning Design and Operation of Pedestrian Facilities".
"Guide for the Development of Bicycle Facilities".
Federal Highway Administration:
"Separated Bike Lane Planning and Design Guide".
"Report on Incorporating On-Road Bicycle Networks into Resurfacing Projects".
Institute of Transportation Engineers, "Manual for Context Sensitive Solutions in Designing Major Urban Thoroughfares for Walkable Communities".
National Cooperative Highway Research Program, Report 616, "Multi-Modal Level of Service Analysis for Urban Streets".

section.heading: Compliance with State and Federal funding requirements.
section.text: The technical design standards required for state or federally funded projects will supersede local requirements in this subtitle and the Complete Streets Manual if there is an actual conflict between the local and state or federal standards and if funding will be impacted by adherence to the local standard.

annotation.text: As indicated in the earlier Editor’s Note to Subtitle, Section 3(1) of Ord. 18-197 provided for the preceding Part V of this subtitle to became effective on that Ordinance’s date of enactment (December 3, 2018) – several months before the delayed effective date set for the rest of this title by Section 5 of Ord. 18-197, as amended by Ord. 19-303 (September 30, 2019).

Section 3 also mandated several activities to be undertaken even during the interim between the two effective dates. Specifically, Section 3(2) et seq., as subsequently amended by Ord. 19-303, provides for the following activities and their respective deadlines:

para.text: On or before October 16, 2019, the Transportation Director, in consultation with the Complete Streets Advisory Committee, shall publish and present to the Transportation Committee a Community Engagement Plan, containing a description of the methods of community engagement to be used to obtain public input. The Plan must include methods to overcome barriers to engagement associated with race, income, age, disability, English language proficiency, and vehicle access and include a means of measuring success in overcoming these barriers. The Plan should demonstrate an earnest application of the recommendations set forth in the ... Letter from Councilmember Ryan Dorsey to then-Transportation Director Mchelle Pourciau (October 19, 2018).

On or before April 1, 2020, the Transportation Director shall, in consultation with the Complete Streets Advisory Committee, propose and publish for public comment a proposed Complete Streets Manual, in accordance with City Code, Article 26, Subtitle 40, Part V, as enacted by this Ordinance.
On or before July 1, 2020, the Transportation Director shall adopt and publish a Complete Streets Manual.

From the date of the enactment of this Ordinance and until the Transportation Director has adopted and published the Complete Streets Manual, the Chair of the Complete Streets Advisory Committee shall provide to the Transportation Committee written bi-weekly progress reports on development of the Complete Streets Manual and on the status of community engagement related to the implementation of this Ordinance.

section.heading: Director to adopt Complete Streets Manual.
section.text: The Transportation Director, in consultation with the Complete Streets Advisory Committee, must adopt and may amend from time to time a Complete Streets Manual to carry out this subtitle.

section.heading: Modal hierarchy.
section.text: The Complete Streets Manual must include a hierarchy of the various modes of travel, indicating the priority to be given to each mode.

para.heading: In General.
para.text: The Complete Streets Manual must include Complete Streets street typologies for classifying City streets.

para.heading: Considerations.
para.text: In creating street typologies, the Transportation Director, in consultation with the Advisory Committee, must consider:
roadway form and function, including traffic volume, speed, and functional classification;
intersections and crossings;
bridges and overpasses;
loading zones;
overlays, including for transit streets, truck routes, and fire and emergency routes;
existing land use;
zoning designations;
public space guidelines;
stormwater management;
green infrastructure;
"Main Streets", as part of the Baltimore Main Streets program;
public art;
arts districts;
historic preservation;
plans formally adopted by the Planning Commission; and
any other necessary considerations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Complete Streets Manual must include a process for identifying, screening, and prioritizing projects seeking funding through federal or state grants, the City Capital Improvement Program, or other means.

para.heading: Process to include equity assessment.
para.text: This project prioritization process must include an equity assessment. The equity assessment must consider transportation disparity trends based on race, gender, sexual orientation, age, disability, ethnicity, national origin, or income and recommend ways to reverse these trends. It must assess and recommend ways to eliminate structural and institutional discrimination in transportation based on immutable characteristics.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Complete Streets Manual must include a project delivery process.

para.heading: Requirements.
para.text: This project delivery process must include:
project phases from identification through construction through operation;

a chart listing the types of projects undertaken by, under the authority of, or under the supervision of the Department, and showing project phases for each type, and steps to complete each project phase, and whether, for each project type, a given step is required, optional, or inapplicable;

a decision tree showing how street typology, existing and planned land use, modal hierarchy, and any additional factors determine street design, and whether various elements are required, recommended, optional, or not required; and
a project management checklist.

section.heading: Equity in community engagement.
section.text: The Complete Streets Manual must include community engagement policies that overcome barriers to engagement associated with race, income, age, disability, English language proficiency, and vehicle access of populations affected by a project, including a means of measuring success in overcoming these barriers.

para.heading: Publication of proposed Manual or amendment.
para.text: The Transportation Director must publish the proposed Complete Streets Manual or proposed amendment to the Manual by posting a copy of the proposal to the Department's website at least 45 days before its adoption.

A notice of the proposed Manual or proposed amendment to the Manual must also be posted to the Transportation Department's website, social media, and other channels of distribution available to the Department.
This notice must include:
a summary of the proposed Manual or proposed amendment; and
information on how a person can:
obtain a copy of the proposal;
obtain a schedule of public hearing(s) to be held on the proposal; and
submit comments before the proposal is finalized and adopted.
During the 45-day public comment period, the Director must also advertise and hold 1 or more public hearings on the proposed Manual or proposed amendment.
At least 1 hearing must be held in whole or in part between 6 pm and 8 pm.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: After the 45-day public comment and hearing period, the Director may modify and adopt the Complete Streets Manual.

para.heading: Filing with Legislative Reference.
para.text: A copy of the Complete Streets Manual and, from time to time, any amendment to the Manual must be filed with the Department of Legislative Reference before it becomes effective.

para.heading: Complete Streets Manual compliance.
para.text: DOT guidelines, policies, and procedures must be updated for compliance with the Complete Streets Manual.

section.heading: Annual report required.
section.text: On or before August 31 of each year, the Director, in consultation with the Advisory Committee, must:

para.text: prepare a report assessing the status of the Complete Streets Transportation System; and
submit that report to:
the Mayor;
the City Council; and
the Advisory Committee.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Performance measures will be established using available data.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The annual report must measure year-over-year changes in crash data for all modes of travel as measured by:
the "Maryland Statewide Vehicle Crashes Data" collected by the Maryland State Police;
the "Fatality Analysis Reporting System" data collected by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration; or
other similar data.

para.heading: Separate reporting by category.
para.text: Crash data for all modes of travel must be separately reported by the following categories:
all crashes;
injury crashes; and
fatal crashes.

para.heading: Transit on-time performance.
para.text: The annual report must measure year-over-year change in transit on-time performance, as measured by:
the performance data collected by the Maryland Transit Administration and published in the Maryland Department of Transportation's Annual Attainment Report; or
other similar data collected by the Maryland Transit Administration or the Transportation Department.

para.heading: Commute times.
para.text: The annual report must measure commute times for all modes of travel, as measured by the travel-time-to-work data reported in the American Communities Survey's "Commuting (Journey to Work)".

para.heading: Modal share.
para.text: The annual report must measure modal share, as measured by the means-of-transportation data reported in the American Communities Survey's "Commuting (Journey to Work)".

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The annual report must measure:
the amount of transportation infrastructure built, upgraded, replaced, or rehabilitated in the previous 1-year period; and
the total amount of infrastructure in the City's overall transportation system.

para.heading: Separate reporting by type.
para.text: The measurements required by paragraph (1) of this subsection must be separately reported by type, including:
infrastructure for walking, biking, and public transit;
public space infrastructure; and
green infrastructure.

para.heading: Economic development measures.
para.text: The annual report must measure year-over-year changes in certain economic development data points and conditions:
in each of the City's "Main Streets", as part of the Baltimore Main Streets program; and
in any other geographical area otherwise designated by the Advisory Committee.

para.heading: Inventory of projects.
para.text: The annual report must include an inventory of all ongoing projects in any phase and the projected cost of those projects.

para.heading: Conflicts between local and state or federal standards.
para.text: The annual report must include a list of all instances in which the local standards set forth in this subtitle or in the Complete Streets Manual were or are planned to be superseded by state or federal standards, pursuant to § 40-31 of this subtitle, as well as citations and causes for the local standard being superseded.

para.heading: Separate reporting by geographic subunit.
para.text: In preparing the annual report, the Department must separately report data by geographic subunit (e.g., census tract, traffic analysis zone, or the like).

para.heading: Separate reporting by race, income, and vehicle access.
para.text: The annual report must separately report data into the following categories:
populations that are above and below the median number of persons of color for Baltimore City.
populations above and below 50% no vehicle access.
populations with a median income above and below the median household income for Baltimore City.

section.heading: Report and data to be publically available.

para.heading: Report to be posted.
para.text: The annual report must be made available to the public by posting it on the Transportation Department's website.

para.heading: Data to be made available.
para.text: To the greatest extent possible, all underlying data used in preparing the annual report must be made available to the public.

section.heading: Accountability to communities.
section.text: The Transportation Department, in consultation with the Complete Streets Advisory Committee, must conduct public meetings and other community engagement and outreach activities to present the Complete Streets annual report to the public and solicit public input.
